results.title: Living Melbourne 1896-1910
results.creator_credit: Chris Long and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: Melbourne’s oldest surviving films are assembled on this compilation, with stills and supporting commentary by film historian Chris Long. Films include the 1896 Melbourne Cup, the opening of Federal Parliament (1901), excerpts from The Story of the Kelly Gang (1906), Marvellous Melbourne (1910), extracts from Living Hawthorn (1907) and Football Final (1910).
results.creator_credit_for_label: Chris Long and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia

results.title: Sunny and the dark horse
results.creator_credit: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and AIAS Film Unit
results.brief_description: This is a companion to the documentaries ‘Stockman’s Strategy’ and ‘Collum Calling Canberra’. Sunny Bancroft, the Aboriginal manager of a co-operative cattle station in northern New South Wales is the central ‘character’ in what is the most narratively-oriented of the trilogy. We follow Sunny as he indulges his passion for horses by acquiring and training a galloper for the picnic races.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David MacDougall, Judith MacDougall and AIAS Film Unit

results.title: Touch the Sun: Top enders
results.creator_credit: Michael Aitkens, Jackie McKimmie, Jill Robb and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Touch the Sun’.
Alice, a runaway from home, meets on the road Mick, a boy in pursuit of his uncle. Stealing a car they traverse a treacherous stretch of desert road. When the car runs out of petrol they set out on foot only to become lost. With the harsh desert conditions threatening their survival Alice and Mick reflect on their actions and the families they have fled from. Cast includes John Jarratt, Madeleine Blackwell, Bennendine Woods, Donald Dale.

results.title: Touch the Sun: Devil's Hill
results.creator_credit: Esben Storm, Jill Robb, Revcom Television, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Touch the Sun’.
Sam and his sisters come to stay on their cousin’s remote farm in Tasmania. Badge, the farm boy, feels daunted by the arrival of his arrogant city cousins. After a huge violent storm, the prize cow escapes. The children decide to search the mountainous wilderness for the cow and their route leads up to the mysterious Devil’s Hill. The adventure teaches them they must stick together to survive. Based on the novel by Nan Chauncy.
Cast includes Peter Hehir, Mary Haire, John Flaus, Alexander Jacobs, Emma Pugh, Cameron Atkins and Jane McArthur.

results.title: Touch the Sun: Captain Johnno
results.creator_credit: Mario Andreacchio, Jane Ballantyne and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series ‘Touch the Sun’.
Johnno, an energetic and sensitive 10 year old, resides in a small coastal fishing town. His father’s inability to come to terms with Johnno’s deafness exacerbates their already troubled relationship. To curb Johnno’s rebelliousness, his father proposes to send him to a “special school”. On learning of this plan Johnno flees to a nearby island to live like Robinson Crusoe. An Italian fisherman, who has earlier befriended Johnno, finds him on the island and endeavours to persuade him to return and face his problems. Cast includes: Damien Walters - Captain Johnno Rebecca Sykes - Julie Michelle Fawdon - Kathleen Joe Petruzzi - Tony Written by Rob George, music by Stephen Matters. Rated G.

results.title: Jazz scrapbook
results.brief_description:
A recollection of Melbourne’s early jazz years with Benny Featherstone, Frank Johnson, Les Barnard and Graeme Bell.
[The film reflects times past has some scenes that may not sit well with contemporary viewers.]

results.title: Signatures of the Soul
results.brief_description: Counter-cultural icon Peter Fonda takes us on a comprehensive journey through the world of tattooing. From early tribal origins and eastern influences, right through to adoption in the mainstream and gradual acceptance as an art form, tattooing has been elevated to both art and an intense form of self-expression.

results.title: The Spag [released version]
results.brief_description: Director Giorgio Mangiamele produced the first examples of multicultural cinema in this country. ‘The Spag’ was shot in the streets of Carlton and tells the story of a newspaper boy working to support his widowed mother; along the way his life is fraught with racism. The film is Neo-Realist in style and makes interesting use of incidental music and post-sync dubbed dialogue track; a dog’s bark is even mimicked by an actor’s voice. Stars the young Terry Donovan.

results.title: Black Sunday
results.brief_description: Depicts the devastation caused by the notorious ‘Black Sunday’ bushfires of 1926, that wiped out the south-east of Victoria.

results.title: [St Kilda Esplanade]
results.brief_description: Early footage of St Kilda, Victoria, showing the entrance to Luna Park with a group of people walking past and chatting outside the Daylight Picture Cinema next door. Ends with a group of people standing on a small jetty on the beach.
